Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Extending Open Access By Bridging the Data Steward Gap: GO FAIR Train-the-Trainer (T3)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
There are national calls for improved production of research data that are FAIR (Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable) in order to increase scientific discovery and enhance the societal and economic benefit of federal research and development (R&D) funding. To stimulate growth of such a FAIR data ecosystem in the U.S., the concrete action taken by this project is to increase expert knowledge of FAIR-oriented tools and techniques, thereby creating new capacity for increasing the value of new and existing data sets. Developing a community of practice for making data FAIR and increasing the network of available expert trainers available will serve to accelerate awareness and build new knowledge in application of FAIR techniques in the U.S.

By means of a two-and-a-half-day intensive training session, the project will bring together practitioners and consultants from academia, non-profits, and industry. The intended audience for the course is seasoned data stewards and researchers, research computing staff with depth in data-driven research, and library and informaticists. The trained teachers will be prepared to teach researchers, data experts, and research library staff at universities and research institutions who are dealing with the ever-growing complexity of data integration.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Research data and software are important components of the scientific and scholarly enterprise, requiring management and maintenance for assessing claims and building new knowledge. As stores of data grow, it is increasingly important to assure that these resources are FAIR - "Findable - Accessible - Interoperable - Reusable," by both humans and machines. This will require professionals with a new breadth of skills, to assess, organize, add valuable information in the form of metadata, and manage access and preservation. FAIR Data Stewardship training is a viable approach to solving some parts of this vast challenge. A combination of more data stewards, and increased FAIR data stewardship skills across research computing staff, libraries, research staff (PIs, postdocs, graduate students), university leaders and funders, and (software) developers, will be necessary to create and nurture an internet of FAIR data.

To address some of these challenges, a workshop was held for 24 experienced information and data professionals to learn about FAIR curriculum and technologies, and consider institutional and research community needs for managing growing stores of data and anticipated federal research policies on data sharing. The GO FAIR US office (based at the San Diego Supercomputer Center) collaborated with Phortos Consultants and experts from the GO FAIR Foundation in the EU to plan and produce this workshop, which was hosted in partnership with the South Big Data Innovation Hub at GA Tech in Atlanta. An external Advisory Group was engaged to provide feedback and recommendations on program content and approach, as well as marketing and participant recruiting; the group?s input was highly valuable and contributed to this success of the event.

Beneficial outcomes from this workshop include a growing network of FAIR-aware data experts from academia, the business community, and federal research agencies, who are interested in building FAIR capacity at their local organizations and the broader research enterprise. This emergent community of practice continues to engage with SDSC and the GO FAIR US office on new FAIR data and policy activities; some have reported subsequent presentations in their home institutions based on their participation in the workshop. More broadly, several additional training and professional development activities were developed as a result of this initial Advancing FAIR workshop, including conference presentations and webinars. Equally significant, the GO FAIR US office team has grown as a direct result of the workshop and now includes several data leaders with distinct expertise. This is expanding our outreach with research communities nationwide, and opening new opportunities for training.
